dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Five hundred billion dollars? That's an enormous price tag for what sounds like a pretty modest infrastructure update.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Five hundred billion dollars? That's an enormous price tag for what sounds like a pretty modest infrastructure update.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The $2 trillion Biden will ask Congress to approve for his American Jobs Plan will be spent over a period of eight years and paid for with tax hikes over a period of 15 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I know, it seems like a lot, but honestly, the breakdown is actually pretty targeted. Two hundred billion of that is just for transportation—roads, bridges, and a big chunk for electric vehicles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, it seems like a lot, but honestly, the breakdown is actually pretty targeted. Two hundred billion of that is just for transportation-roads, bridges, and a big chunk for electric vehicles.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Included in that $2 trillion is $621 billion for transportation infrastructure like roads and bridges, with $174 billion of that set aside for the electric vehicle market, $111 billion for clean drinking water, $100 billion for expanding broadband and $100 billion for power infrastructure like the electric grid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But they're paying for it with spending cuts over ten years? That feels like kicking the can down the road. And lowering the corporate tax rate to 21%—isn't that a bit contradictory if you're trying to fund new programs?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But they're paying for it with spending cuts over ten years? That feels like kicking the can down the road. And lowering the corporate tax rate to twenty one percent-isn't that a bit contradictory if you're trying to fund new programs?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To help pay for all that spending, the Biden administration is expected to propose a series of major tax changes including raising the corporate rate from 21% to 28% and raising the global minimum tax.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the idea is that by making some tax adjustments, they can still cover the costs without adding to the deficit. And hey, there's funding for clean water, broadband expansion—stuff both parties usually say they want.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the idea is that by making some tax adjustments, they can still cover the costs without adding to the deficit. And hey, there's funding for clean water, broadband expansion-stuff both parties usually say they want.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Included in that $2 trillion is $621 billion for transportation infrastructure like roads and bridges, with $174 billion of that set aside for the electric vehicle market, $111 billion for clean drinking water, $100 billion for expanding broadband and $100 billion for power infrastructure like the electric grid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but Mitch McConnell is already calling it "way too much." And didn't the last bill, the American Safety Act, just pass with mostly Republican support? This feels like it's gonna be a tougher sell.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but Mitch McConnell is already calling it way too much. And didn't the last bill, the American Safety Act, just pass with mostly Republican support? This feels like it's gonna be a tougher sell.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The American Jobs plan follows the $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan, which Biden signed into law earlier this month. The American Rescue Plan was passed by Democrats over the objections of the Republican party using a special legislative process called budget reconciliation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, but remember, that one had stimulus checks and unemployment adjustments—popular stuff. This is more long-term investment. Plus, there's workforce development money, which could help offset any job losses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but remember, that one had stimulus checks and unemployment adjustments-popular stuff. This is more long-term investment. Plus, there's workforce development money, which could help offset any job losses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That legislation included a third round of stimulus checks in the amount of $1,400, an extension of the $300-per-week federal unemployment insurance supplement, a major expansion of the child tax credit (among other tax relief initiatives) and billions of dollars for rental, mortgage and food assistance and vaccines and healthcare to see the country through the pandemic. Theres also $213 billion for affordable and sustainable housing, $400 billion for the care economy and $100 billion for workforce development.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Speaking of jobs, the text mentions discouraging domestic manufacturing? That seems counterintuitive for a "Build America" plan.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Speaking of jobs, the text mentions discouraging domestic manufacturing? That seems counterintuitive for a Build America plan.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biden also wants to encourage domestic manufacturing by making it more expensive for American companies to produce goods and services overseas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, yeah, that part is confusing. It says it'll be more economical for companies to produce overseas, which uh, doesn't really align with boosting local jobs. Maybe there's more nuance there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, yeah, that part is confusing. It says it'll be more economical for companies to produce overseas, which uh, doesn't really align with boosting local jobs. Maybe there's more nuance there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biden also wants to encourage domestic manufacturing by making it more expensive for American companies to produce goods and services overseas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Or maybe it's just a poorly thought-out detail. And Goldman Sachs analysts are already eyeing semiconductor manufacturers as winners if domestic production gets hindered? That's concerning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or maybe it's just a poorly thought-out detail. And Goldman Sachs analysts are already eyeing semiconductor manufacturers as winners if domestic production gets hindered? That's concerning.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Analysts from Bank of America predict that companies that manufacture the equipment used to make semiconductorsthe computer chips found in everything from cars to smartphonesare poised to profit from Bidens push to modernize the United States digital infrastructure and shore up domestic production of the essential computer components as part of his $2 trillion plan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure, that tangent raises questions. But look, this is only part one—next month she's expected to roll out climate and defense measures. Maybe those will balance things out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure, that tangent raises questions. But look, this is only part one-next month she's expected to roll out climate and defense measures. Maybe those will balance things out.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biden is expected to introduce the second part of his American Jobs Plan next month. That proposal will include provisions related to healthcare and childcare.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Maybe. I'm skeptical this scaled-down approach will satisfy either side, though. Progressives want bolder action, conservatives think it's too expensive already.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Maybe. I'm skeptical this scaled-down approach will satisfy either side, though. Progressives want bolder action, conservatives think it's too expensive already.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Republicans are sure to balk at the price tag and the potential repeal of many of President Trumps tax cuts for big companies and wealthy individuals to pay for the plan, some progressives are saying the package should be larger. This is not nearly enough, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tweeted Tuesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a tricky tightrope. But given the political realities, maybe this is the most they can push through right now. We'll have to see how the votes shake out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a tricky tightrope. But given the political realities, maybe this is the most they can push through right now. We'll have to see how the votes shake out.

artist_script:
HostA: Five hundred billion dollars? That's an enormous price tag for what sounds like a pretty modest infrastructure update.
HostB: I know, it seems like a lot, but honestly, the breakdown is actually pretty targeted. Two hundred billion of that is just for transportation—roads, bridges, and a big chunk for electric vehicles.
HostA: But they're paying for it with spending cuts over ten years? That feels like kicking the can down the road. And lowering the corporate tax rate to 21%—isn’t that a bit contradictory if you're trying to fund new programs?
HostB: Well, the idea is that by making some tax adjustments, they can still cover the costs without adding to the deficit. And hey, there's funding for clean water, broadband expansion—stuff both parties usually say they want.
HostA: Yeah, but Mitch McConnell is already calling it "way too much." And didn’t the last bill, the American Safety Act, just pass with mostly Republican support? This feels like it’s gonna be a tougher sell.
HostB: True, but remember, that one had stimulus checks and unemployment adjustments—popular stuff. This is more long-term investment. Plus, there’s workforce development money, which could help offset any job losses.
HostA: Speaking of jobs, the text mentions discouraging domestic manufacturing? That seems counterintuitive for a "Build America" plan.
HostB: Uh, yeah, that part is confusing. It says it’ll be more economical for companies to produce overseas, which uh, doesn’t really align with boosting local jobs. Maybe there’s more nuance there.
HostA: Or maybe it’s just a poorly thought-out detail. And Goldman Sachs analysts are already eyeing semiconductor manufacturers as winners if domestic production gets hindered? That’s concerning.
HostB: For sure, that tangent raises questions. But look, this is only part one—next month she’s expected to roll out climate and defense measures. Maybe those will balance things out.
HostA: Maybe. I’m skeptical this scaled-down approach will satisfy either side, though. Progressives want bolder action, conservatives think it’s too expensive already.
HostB: Yeah, it’s a tricky tightrope. But given the political realities, maybe this is the most they can push through right now. We’ll have to see how the votes shake out.
